header_summary:
The Bitcoin development community has migrated its mailing list to Google Groups, necessitating stakeholders to subscribe anew via email or through the [Google Groups interface](https://groups.google.com/g/bitcoindev). Historical records are accessible at [gnusha.org](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev) and can be downloaded in full from [diyhpl.us](https://diyhpl.us/~bryan/irc/bitcoin/bitcoin-dev/bitcoin-dev-ml-archive.2024-02-09-004.tar.gz). Participants are advised to use email filters for organization and to post with the community's best interest in mind; Joe Rayhawk's contribution to the transition was recognized, and moderator contacts are available for support.

In the realm of Bitcoin Improvement Proposals (BIPs), there's active discussion about a new proposal (bLIP) for the Lightning Network, which can be reviewed at [blips/pull/32](https://github.com/lightning/blips/pull/32). The bLIP suggests a wildcard DNS strategy to streamline Lightning Network protocols and proposes additional steps in the invoice request process, with ongoing debates on further optimizations.

The community is also examining fee estimation accuracy on the blockchain, recognizing that excluding transactions with unconfirmed parents does not compromise model precision. The discourse is pivoting towards a new fee estimation framework that incorporates package relay and validation, addressing misclassifications and accommodating transaction bundling, which is pivotal for enhancing the fee estimator's future effectiveness.

recent_posts.summary:

active_posts.title: V3 transaction policy for anti-pinning
active_posts.summary:
- Gloria Zhao proposed "V3" to solve Bitcoin's transaction pinning issue.
- Greg Sanders' ephemeral anchors concept is considered alongside V3.
- A Bitcoin Core pull request outlines V3 policy's implementation steps.

active_posts.title: [BUG]: spammers get Bitcoin blockspace at discounted price. Let's fix it
active_posts.summary:
- Blockspace pricing disparities exist between simple and complex Bitcoin transactions.
- Uniform pricing for blockspace is proposed to prevent network inefficiencies and centralization.
- Implementation of equal cost per byte in Segwit may normalize transaction expenses.

active_posts.title: An overview of the cluster mempool proposal
active_posts.summary:
- A proposed Bitcoin Core mempool design emphasizes cluster size limits and updating RBF rules.
- The new design aligns eviction and mining algorithms, advocating for a total ordering of transactions.
- It promises to streamline mining and eviction, eliminating ancestor/descendant limits and simplifying processing.

today_in_history_posts.title: BIP151 protocol incompatibility
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- BIP151 proposal's claim of backward compatibility is wrong as non-supporting peers will ignore encinit messages.
- Sending unexpected content to existing nodes is an incompatibility, potentially leading to DOS attacks.
- The protocol level is established post-version handshake, rendering the change non-backward compatible.

today_in_history_posts.title: Transaction revocation within transaction	malleability via anyone-can-revoke hashlocks
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Rusty Russell suggests a method to address transaction malleability with a revocable output.
- The method requires a revocation key and times for spending by different parties involved.
- Russell notes potential theft by miners and suggests using Tadge's watchers for DoS attacks.

today_in_history_posts.title: Deflationary money is a Good Thing
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Passive investment includes acquiring assets like land or gold without active management.
- Active investors engage directly in activities like developing land or managing rentals.
- The article suggests central banks could issue inflationary currency backed by Bitcoin.
